author: HoopsHype
title: Draymond Green on Klay Thompson leaving: I'm happy he's gone because he wasn't happy being here anymore
text:
ClutchPoints:
Source:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy as hell he gone. The reason I‚Äôm happy he‚Äôs gone is because he wasn‚Äôt happy no more. As a brother, I only want what‚Äôs best for you, not what‚Äôs best for me, not what‚Äôs best for this team.‚ÄùDraymond Green on Klay Thompson going to the Mavs üëÄ pic.twitter.com/wwNORTZ6qm
Source:
Twitter @ClutchPointsApp
What‚Äôs the buzz on Twitter?
Chris Biderman@ TheWarriorsWire
Buddy Hield isn‚Äôt feeling pressure to replace Klay Thompson
warriorswire.usatoday.com/2024/07/23/bud‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/R6XAg9zcLg‚Äì 4:05 AM Chris Biderman@ TheWarriorsWire
Buddy Hield isn‚Äôt feeling pressure to replace Klay Thompson
https://t.co/0zR2lYmVUA pic.twitter.com/rIQlPwbByt‚Äì 3:00 AM Chris Biderman@ TheWarriorsWire
Buddy Hield isn‚Äôt feeling pressure to replace Klay Thompson
https://t.co/RSBw0qnmVD pic.twitter.com/VydpiXRz4Y‚Äì 2:00 PM
More on
[ this storyline](/player/draymond-green//)
Recently, Green took to the Club 520 podcast to discuss how long he believes he has left in the NBA. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm on the wrong side of my down slide, like I‚Äôm headed into year 13,‚Äù said Green, via Club 520 on YouTube.
‚ÄúI probably got two more. And so it‚Äôs important to start building for the next thing, but for some of these guys they be in year three still trying to figure it out with the podcast.Like I love that you‚Äôre doing it, I love that you found something that you want to do, but you in year three and ain‚Äôt done s‚Äìt nobody really want to hear from you, you know what I‚Äôm saying.‚Äù -via Clutch Points/ July 25, 2024
ClutchPoints:
[‚Äú[The Warriors] were about to make a trade last week‚Ä¶ That‚Äôs a bad trade, don‚Äôt do that trade‚Ä¶ Although it going to help me right now.‚Äù]https://hoopshype.com/social/‚Äî Draymond Green üëÄ (via @club520podcast) pic.twitter.com/98jktKHJM8 -via Twitter @ClutchPointsApp/ July 25, 2024
NBA Central:
Draymond Green and Kentavious Caldwell-Pope both say they heard players on the Clippers quit in the bubble, even while up 3-1, and wanted to go home üò≥(üé• @TheVolumeSports ) pic.twitter.com/qd9zRbUupX -via Twitter @TheNBACentral/ July 24, 2024 Brandin Podziemski on Klay Thompson: ‚ÄúGetting a call from him a couple of days ago, and him telling me I‚Äôll always have a brother in him for life is pretty cool.We can‚Äôt wait to go against him and compete against him when we play Dallas.‚Äù -via NBC Sports Bay Area/ July 20, 2024 ‚ÄúIt meant a lot,‚Äù Brandin Podziemski told Chris Haynes of Klay Thompson‚Äôs mentorship during the 2023-24 NBA season. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something you can‚Äôt just go on Google or go on YouTube and search upwhen you get advice from someone like that. And so for me, just appreciating his presence, appreciating everything he shared with me from an on-court and off-court perspective.‚Äù -via NBC Sports Bay Area/ July 20, 2024
The Lakers‚Äô inactivity has not been due to a lack of trying. They struck out with Klay Thompson, were unable to land other impact free agents like Jonas Valanƒçi≈´nas and DeMar DeRozan, and have failed thus far to find common ground in trade talks with Portland, Brooklyn, Utah, Toronto and Orlando. Now,
according to league and team sources, the Lakers are expected to remain patient in their quest to improve their roster. -via New York Times/ July 17, 2024

author: Jeff Dodge
title: 1000-Lb Sisters Tammy Slaton Reveals If She Finally Loves Herself Amid New Living Situation & Weight Loss Transformation
text: [1000-Lb Sisters](https://screenrant.com/tag/1000-lb-sisters) star Tammy Slaton delivered a powerful and inspiring message to her followers, which included a reminder about self-love. Tammy and her family have [starred on 1000-Lb Sisters since 2000](https://screenrant.com/tammy-slaton-grown-1000-lb-sisters-season-1/). She and Amy are the two most prominent cast members, as their reality show has featured their extraordinary weight loss journeys. [Tammy recently announced she lost 500 pounds](https://screenrant.com/1000-lb-sisters-tammy-slaton-dramatic-full-length-photos-500-pound-weight-loss-journey-pictures/). At a recent doctor's appointment, which was shown on 1000-Lb Sisters, conversations have started over when Tammy can undergo skin removal surgery. 1000-Lb Sisters ' Tammy Slaton sent a powerful message to her followers about pushing through life's many obstacles and overcoming struggles. In her latest Instagram post, [Tammy](https://www.instagram.com/queentammy86/reel/DCC1_juy76c/) shared a video that showed her looking directly at the camera and sending a powerful message to her social media followers about pushing through life's many obstacles and overcoming struggles. In the post's caption, she talked about the need to build strength and resilience, and mentioned that the "path to becoming the best version of yourself" is to build up "self-love," which is a trait that she has finally gained on her weight loss journey. She reminded her fans that "every step forward counts," even though it won't always be easy. Tammy added that everybody struggling to overcome various challenges owes it "to yourself to keep going, to keep growing and to never settle." The 1000-Lb Sisters star ended her Instagram post by telling her fans to keep pushing forward, to keep believing in themselves and to never forget that they are "capable of amazing things." Over 15,000 people have liked the post so far, and over 400 of them replied in the comments section saying how inspiring Tammy is; some even said they needed to hear this message today. What Tammy Slaton‚Äôs Inspiring Message About Building Self-Love Means Tammy's Transformation Isn't Just About Losing Weight Tammy has come a long way since 1000-Lb Sisters first debuted in 2020. She wasn't happy with her life, and she was more prone to negativity. The most obvious shift in her transformation is her weight loss. She has lost at least 500 pounds at this point, an accomplishment that should be applauded. [Related ](/best-reality-tv-shows-right-now/) [ 20 Best Reality TV Shows Right Now ](/best-reality-tv-shows-right-now/) Reality TV is more popular than ever. With so many to choose from, here are some of the best reality TV shows to stream or watch right now. However, that's not her only transformation. The more weight she loses, the more she gains more and more control over her life. Part of that control includes [Tammy's mental health and well-being](https://screenrant.com/1000-lb-sisters-tammy-slaton-mental-health-struggles-weight-loss-journey-physical-emotional-well-being/). The 1000-Lb Sisters star is a lot more happy and positive now. She's finally loving life again and, more important, loves herself now. That talk of building up "self-love" in her Instagram post is possible because she has managed to instill that in herself first. Our Take On Tammy Slaton Becoming The Best Version Of Herself Tammy Wants To Be An Inspiration To Her Fans Tammy is at a point in her journey where she wants to give back to the community. She is an inspiration to so many people, as evidenced by the numerous online comments from her fans. Now that she knows she can accomplish anything, she wants to ensure that other people know they can do it too. It takes a lot of hard work and determination, but if you can manage to overcome these hurdles, then the rewards on the other side are worth it. 1000-Lb SIsters airs Tuesdays at 9 p.m. EST on TLC. Source: [Tammy Slaton](https://www.instagram.com/queentammy86/reel/DCC1_juy76c/)/Instagram

author: Libby Emmons
title: Trump's request for new trial in E. Jean Carroll defamation case denied by federal judge
text: President Donald Trump requested a new trial in the civil case brought against him by advice columnist [E. Jean Carroll](https://thepostmillennial.com/e-jean-carroll-parties-with-media-elites-in-nyc-after-83-million-award-in-trump-defamation-case), who alleged that at some point she could not precisely remember in the mid-1990s he had sexually assaulted her in the dressing room of Bergdorf Goodman department store in midtown Manhattan, and that request has been denied by a federal judge. Carroll was awarded [$83 million](https://thepostmillennial.com/breaking-president-trump-ordered-to-pay-83-million-for-defaming-e-jean-carroll) in a defamation suit following a win in her civil suit, in which a New York City judge and jury determined that Trump was civilly liable for sexual assault. The case did not meet the bar for a criminal prosecution. In addition to denying Trump's request for a new trial, district judge [Lewis A. Kaplan](https://thepostmillennial.com/breaking-e-jean-carroll-lawyer-considering-another-defamation-suit-against-trump) also said that Trump must pay out the $83 million, for which he has posted bond. The damages were for what were alleged to be reputational damages to Carroll, sustained when Trump defended himself publicly against her allegations. This was classified as defamation. Carroll's accusations against Trump were revealed in a tell-all expose she penned for The New York Magazine in 2019 at the height of the #MeToo movement when society at large was ready to "believe all women." Trump called her a "wack job" and said he never met her about 5 hours after the story was published. These were the comments Carroll alleged caused her $83 million worth of harm. Carroll has been featured on talk show and in publications ever since 2019 and has been praised by legacy media for her alleged bravery in coming forward. After she was awarded $83 million in the defamation suit, MSNBC pundit [Rachel Maddow](https://thepostmillennial.com/new-e-jean-carroll-says-shes-taking-rachel-maddow-shopping-for-luxury-items-with-83-million-trump-award-to-help-shore-up-womens-rights) asked Carroll what she would do with the money, to which she replied that she would "go shopping" and offered to buy Maddow a penthouse. In his decision denying Trump's request for a new trial, Kaplan said that Trump's reasons were insufficient. Trump's attorneys said that the plaintiff had to prove that Trump spoke out against Carroll and her allegations with the intent to harm her, that he was motivated by common law malice and nothing else, and that the plaintiff had not done so. Kaplan said they didn't have to prove that. Further, Trump's attorneys said that the burden of proof for the case should be more than a "preponderance of the evidence," that the jury in the case should have been instructed to make their determination based on "clear and convincing evidence." This argument also did not meet with Kaplan's approval. In defending the rulings, Kaplan repeatedly referred to the plaintiff's arguments that the plaintiff should win the large sum. In other words, Trump wanted a higher bar of proof for the plaintiff to have to meet, but the judge said that wasn't necessary, and that the low bar was fine. While Trump states that the $83 million is excessive, Kaplan stated in his ruling that "contrary to the defendant's arguments, Ms. Carroll's compensatory damages were not awarded solely for her emotional distress; they were not for garden variety harms, and they were not excessive, for all of the reasons stated in Ms. Carroll's opposition brief." Kaplan leaned into the then-president's reach on social media, claiming that because he had broadcast his statements of self-defense against what he claims is Carroll's defamation against him, the alleged defamation against Carroll was that much worse. While he posited that Trump's comments were visible to millions, Kaplan said that there "is no evidence at all as to the dissemination of The Cut article to which defendant seeks to assign all of the damages suffered by Ms. Carroll and which was not even alleged to have been defamatory." Kaplan may not be familiar with website traffic, which every online publication has been obsessed with since the internet became a newsstand. "Mr. Trump‚Äôs malicious and unceasing attacks on Ms. Carroll were disseminated to more than 100 million people. They included public threats and personal attacks, and they endangered Ms. Carroll‚Äôs health and safety. The jury was entitled to conclude that Mr. Trump derailed the career, reputation, and emotional well-being of one of America‚Äôs most successful and prominent advice columnists and authors ‚Äî to which she testified repeatedly29 ‚Äî and award her $18.3 million in compensatory damages," Kaplan said. It was because he was president, Kaplan said, and had such a wide audience, that his comments were harmful. "The jury was entitled to find that 'the degree of reprehensibility' of Mr. Trump‚Äôs 14 conduct was remarkably high, perhaps unprecedented. Far from being purely 'defensive,' there was evidence that Mr. Trump used the office of the presidency ‚Äî the loudest 'bully pulpit' in America and possibly the world ‚Äî to issue multiple statements castigating Ms. Carroll as a politically and financially motivated liar, insinuating that she was too unattractive for him to have sexually assaulted, and threatening that she would 'pay dearly' for speaking out.‚Äù "The jury could have found that Mr. Trump wielded his position as arguably the most powerful and famous man in the world to broadcast his lies to millions of dedicated followers in an effort to destroy Ms. Carroll‚Äôs credibility, to punish her for coming forward, and to deter other women from doing so as well. It could have found also that he continued his attacks over the nearly five years that it took this case to come to a jury verdict. And there was evidence that Mr. Trump‚Äôs statements about Ms. Carroll only increased in frequency and vitriol as trial approached, with Mr. Trump repeating the same or similar attacks on Ms. Carroll despite knowing that a jury and the Court already had held his similar 2022 statement to have been defamatory." The $83 million, Kaplan said, was meant to act as a deterrent to Trump making remarks against Carroll. "Accordingly, Mr. Trump's motions for a new trial and for a judgement as a matter of law are DENIED." Comments Powered by StructureCMS‚Ñ¢ Comments Join and support independent free thinkers! We‚Äôre independent and can‚Äôt be cancelled. The establishment media is increasingly dedicated to divisive cancel culture, corporate wokeism, and political correctness, all while covering up corruption from the corridors of power. The need for fact-based journalism and thoughtful analysis has never been greater. When you support The Post Millennial, you support freedom of the press at a time when it's under direct attack. Join the ranks of independent, free thinkers by supporting us today for as little as $1.
